comment.author: 10659106@N00
comment._content: Almost an Albatros C.1, but not.

comment.author: 9161595@N03
comment._content: It does seem like something early from Albatros-Flugzeugwerke, but it seems hard to be more specific. On this plane — pardon me for not knowing the terminology here — the plate just behind the propellor seems to be a flat square, while in most of the ones I can find pictures of, e.g. the B.I (1913), the B. II (1914), the C.I (1915) — the same assembly seems to be more of a pyramid or cone shape at that junction. By the time they got to the C.V (1916), the overall design starts looking more rounded & sleek than what we see in this photo, which seems to have a boxier overall airframe. So it does seem to be something in the Albatros B.x or Albatros C.(I, II, III, IV) range. • • • • • Maybe an ALBATROS C-1 C-2?

comment.author: 52583849@N04
comment._content: Definitely NOT an Albatros - none of which have ailerons like that. More likely it is from the US west coast as it shares a certain degree of similarity to the Boeing model C floatplane although the Boeing is more advanced with regard to roll control.

comment.author: 9161595@N03
comment._content: Good catch — you're right, the trailing edge of the wing is different.

comment.author: 77345821@N06
comment._content: It definitely looks like an American design to me. There are two vertical block radiators just in front of the leading edge of the top wing. This is very "Wright-Martin" looking stuff... or similar American producer, Thomas perhaps, prior to the Thomas-Morse merger.
